벢D18-121913베. Right medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CHANGES MOST SUGGESTIVE OF PSORIATIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: An increase in catagen/telogen hairs, increase in miniaturized hairs, and presence of a superficial and deep perivascular and perifollicular lymphoid infiltrate in the absence of significant follicular destruction, are the features that have been described in alopecia associated with psoriasis. The lack of follicular destruction is against a scarring alopecia such as central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia or lichen planopilaris.   Initial and multiple levels were examined. Sections from both biopsies show psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with foci of parakeratosis containing neutrophils (best seen in biopsy B), associated with a superficial perivascular and deep perifollicular lymphoid infiltrate with numerous plasma cells.  There is an increase in catagen/telogen (20 %) and miniaturized hairs, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 1:3 in biopsy B, and approximately 3:1 in biopsy A. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain, in either biopsy. T. pallidum immunostains were performed fro completeness sake (given the number of plasma cells present), which are negative for spirochetal organisms in both biopsies.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%psalo%%  B. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CHANGES MOST SUGGESTIVE OF PSORIATIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%psalo%% 
벢D18-123134베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  There is a ruptured follicular unit. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A PAS stain i negative for hyphae and fails to demonstrate a thickened basement membrane zone.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Elsa Velazquez who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 
벢D18-123711베. Vertex, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: Sections shows increased miniaturization with mild increase in telogen/catagen. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context. The differential diagnosis of histologic findings would also include a recovery phase of an alopecia areata that has gone into remission.  Sections show decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is mildly increased.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling who concurs with the above interpretation.  
벢D18-123921베. Left scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Although the findings are very subtle, there is overall decrease in follicular density associated with concentric fibroplasia and focal patchy interface injury with lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, suggestive of lichen planopilaris. No interfollicular interface injury, increase in dermal mucin, or deep perifollicular inflammation or perivascular inflammation as expected in lupus is seen. Diagnostic features of alopecia areata are no seen. Interpretation is limited due to the small number of follicular units present for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis.  As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Julie Reimann who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 
벢D18-124110베. Right superior scalp, Punch: %%P%% NONSCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: While patchy superficial and deep perivascular lymphoid inflammation is noted, there is no evidence of peribulbar inflammation or increase in catagen/telogen hairs, arguing against superimposed alopecia areata. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. This case was reviewed by Dr. Elsa Velazquez who concurs with the above interpretation.  Approximately 35 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring, and the epidermis is unremarkable. Patchy superficial and deep perivascular lymphoid inflammation is noted. No interface injury or increase in dermal mucin is noted. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 2:1. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 
벢D18-124720베. Frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% COMPATIBLE WITH MORPHEA.  Comment:  Features of alopecia areata are not seen. Sections show increased dermal thickness with broad sclerotic collagen bundles parallel with the epidermis and extending into the subcutis, and diminution of adipose tissue around the adnexal structures which are diminished or lost. This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling and Dr. Michael Zhang who concur with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%morph%% 
벢D18-124849베. Right lower cutaneous lip, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ALOPECIA AREATA, WITH SUPERIMPOSED ECZEMATOUS DERMATITIS.  Comment:   Sections show follicular miniaturization with a modest catagen-telogen shift. While not definitive, these findings in conjunction with the clinical appearance of the lesion are most consistent with alopecia areata. There is no evidence of scarring. There is also follicular epidermal spongiosis and the periodic acid-Schiff stain shows pityrosporum yeast in the stratum corneum, suggestive of a superimposed eczematous or allergic contact dermatitis, or possibly a pityrosporum folliculitis. Although mucinosis is not identified with an alcian blue stain, due to the presence of focal follicular exocytosis of the infiltrate, immunohistichemical stains were performed, which show a non-diagnostic pattern, with variable CD3, CD4 and CD8 expression throughout several levels of the biopsy; however, procurement of levels is limited by the Headington processing technique for alopecia. The H&E and immunophenotypic findings support a reactive process; Since very early stages of cutaneous T-cell dyscrasia can mimic spongiotic dermatitis histologically, however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended, particularly if clinical progression occurs despite conservative therapeutic measures, and/or if the patient has been recently applying topical therapy (as this can affect the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings). This case was reviewed by Drs. Adriano Piris and Christopher Dowling who concur with the above interpretation. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aa%% 
벢D18-124860베. Superior mid forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, supports the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in the proper clinical context.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction. The histological alteration is more significant in one of the two portions of tissues. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. %%ffalo%%%%88305%% %%88312%%

벢D18-127572베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia.  Although the former is favored, differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%lmsa%%%%88312%%

벣D18-161252베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: 34 follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians, approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans). The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission). Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show a minimal decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 
벣D18-161726베. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND PROBABLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs (up to 20% of terminal hairs in some sections), without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with probable concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below).  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING, NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, FAVOR TRAUMATIC ALOPECIA (SEE COMMENT)  Comment: A non-scarring non-inflammatory alopecia is present. There is patchy loss of total hair units and focal perifollicular fibrosis/onion-skinning as can be seen in an early scarring alopecia, however, well-developed scarring alopecia is not identified. Patchy chronic inflammation is present and non-specific; no suppurative folliculitis or dissecting cellulitis is identified. There are slightly increased numbers of telogen follicles with retention of sebaceous glands and a traumatic alopecia is favored, possibly secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania). 벣D18-165779베. Right temporal peak, Biopsy: %%P%% PATCHY EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The changes are not entirely specific, with the differential including one of the scarring alopecias (central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, CCCA, lichen planopilaris, LPP, and lupus erythematosus, LE).  However, rare foci of follicular interface injury is present which favors LPP and LE over CCCA.  Additionally, while lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, favors the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, some of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. Approximately 9 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch). Approximately 50% of the remaining hair follicles are affected by the patchy early scarring perifollicular fibrosis and interface injury.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%

Mild focal perinfundibular inflammation and mild fibrosis are present. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. 벢D18-3559베. Left ant scalp/4 cm hairline, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM WITH LIKELY BACKGROUND OF EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The submitted clinical note and images are reviewed (and are appreciated). The findings in this biopsy show a slight increase in early miniaturization, as well as an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. This increase in telogen hairs is also seen in biopsy B, further supporting the diagnosis of telogen effluvium. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is also favored in this biopsy given the slight increase in hair shaft size variability and slight increase in miniaturized hairs (and the clinical presentation of bifrontal thinning of the hair). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.    Initial and multiple levels were examined. Approximately 32 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 20%. There is a slight increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 3.5:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Right occipital/7 cm ear, Punch biopsy: %%P%% INCREASE IN TELOGEN HAIRS, CONSISTENT WITH TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: Please also see comment in part A. Approximately 26 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. In comparison to biopsy A, no significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles is appreciated (terminal to vellus hair ratio of 5:1). The percent catagen/telogen is increased, at approximately 20 percent. %%88305%%%%te%% 1/12/2018
벢D18-3788베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus.  The lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for hyphae). This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 1/10/2018
벢D18-4607베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCALP BIOPSY WITH FOCAL LYMPHOCYTIC INFLAMMATION AND PIGMENT INCONTINENCE WITHIN COLLAPSED FOLLICULAR STELLA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).   Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the small number of hair follicles present (only 6) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The epidermis is essentially unremarkable, without significant scale formation or spongiosis and diagnostic features of seborrheic dermatitis are not appreciated in the examined sections.  Sebaceous glands are intact and no dermal fibrosis is seen (arguing against a primary scarring alopecia). Presence or absence of miniaturization or increase in telogen hairs cannot be assessed adequately due to the small number of follicles present. While the presence of focal lymphoid inflammation in 2 collapsed stella in the subcutis raises the consideration of alopecia areata in the appropriate clinical context, it is not diagnostic as the histologic differential diagnosis for this finding could also include nonspecific folliculitis, syphilitic alopecia, or the non-cicatricial alopecia that can be associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Initial and multiple levels were examined. The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated). A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).%%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%%1/12/2018

벢D18-7204베. R frontal, Punch biopsy: %%P%% MOST CONSISTENT WITH TRACTION ALOPECIA, LIKELY IN A BACKGROUND OF EARLY FEMALE PATTERN ALOPECIA (Please see comment).  Comment: The findings in this biopsy may be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  There is a decrease in terminal follicle density, without evidence of scarring. There is some evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. There is an increased percentage of miniaturized hair follicles which may represent a background of early female pattern alopecia or may be related to the traction alopecia. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). There are superficial inflammatory changes that may be consistent with associated seborrheic dermatitis. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. 벢D18-7520베. Right frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Mary Tan who concurs with the above interpretation.   Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%1/17/2018

Comment: Sections were incubated with antibodies against IgG, IgM, IgA, C3, fibrin and albumin.  Note that a negative direct immunofluorescence result does not exclude the diagnosis of lupus, as up to approximately fifty percent of biopsies from lesional skin can show negative direct immunofluorescence results in patients with lupus.  In addition, most patients with dermatomyositis present with a negative lupus band. %%88346%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%difneg%%1/19/2018

벢D18-13311베. Left parietal scalp, Punch biopsy 4 mm:%%P%% LYMPHOCYTIC MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, clinical history of oral lichen planus in addition to histological findings such as lack of increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. Only very minimal interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was used in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 1/26/2018

At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. 벢D18-14173베. Left parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.   Initial and multiple levels were examined. Approximately 20 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, sebaceous glands are intact, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of appoximately 1:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%1/26/2018
벢D18-14322베. Right scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  Sections demonstrate a fragment of scalp tissue with mild increase in telogen / catagen follicles and miniaturization.  Features of lupus erythematosus or scarring alopecia are not identified in the current specimen.  Although scattered hairs with loss of internal root sheet are noted, given the clinical impression/ presentation, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is not favored.  However, Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.    %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%  B. Anterior scalp, Punch Biopsy DIF:%%P%% DIRECT IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE OF SKIN-   NO SPECIFIC IMMUNOREACTANTS DETECTED.  Comment: Sections were incubated with antibodies against IgG, IgM, IgA, C3, fibrin and albumin.  Note that a negative direct immunofluorescence result does not exclude the diagnosis of lupus, as up to approximately fifty percent of biopsies from lesional skin can show negative direct immunofluorescence results in patients with lupus.  In addition, most patients with dermatomyositis present with a negative lupus band.  %%88346%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%88350%%%%difneg%% 1/30/2018

The histologic differential diagnosis includes an early androgenetic alopecia (AGA), resolving telogen effluvium (TE) or alopecia areata. 벢D18-16459베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA (SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 1/31/2018

While there is minimal patchy perifollicular inflammation superficially, it is non-specific, and insufficient to establish a diagnosis of lichen planopilaris in this specimen. Characteristic changes of alopecia areata are not appreciated in the examined sections. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling who concurs with the above interpretation. 벢D18-22436베. Left frontal scalp, Punch 3 mm:%%P%% SCALP BIOPSY WITHOUT SIGNIFICANT PATHOLOGIC ABNORMALITIES. PLEASE SEE THE COMMENT.   Comment: The findings in this biopsy are essentially within normal limits, without evidence of a significant increase in miniaturized or telogen hairs, inflammation, or scarring. The lack of significant histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia may be due to an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission), very early androgenetic alopecia with subthreshold diagnostic findings, or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, additional punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered, if clinically indicated.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.   Initial and multiple levels were examined and show a total of 4 hair follicles for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio and percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are essentially within normal limits. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%nlsb%%2/9/2018

벢D18-24326베. Frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%2/12/2018

벢D18-25772베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON SCARRING LYMPHOCYTIC MEDIATED ALOPECIA.   Comment: The biopsy shows increase in miniaturized hair follicles and percentage of catagen/telogen hair, in addition to prominent peribulbar and perieccrine lymphocytic inflammation. These features are all suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus in this biopsy; however, no significant increase in dermal mucin is appreciated.    Other differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated non scarring alopecia include alopecia areata, syphilitic alopecia and psoriatic alopecia. Alopecia areata shows less inflammation overall and lacks perieccrine inflammation seen in this biopsy. No significant increase in plasma cells are noted as expected in syphilitic alopecia. In addition, T. pallidum immunostain is negative for spirochetal organisms. Epidermal changes of psoriasis are not seen. This case was reviewed by Dr. Christopher Dowling and Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concur with the above interpretation.   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%%2/16/2018

벢D18-33095베. Right superior frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.  Approximately 15 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:   Approximately 8 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 2/26/2018

벢D18-36308베. Mid scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCALP BIOPSY WITH PIGMENT CAST AND SLIGHT PERIVASCULAR LYMPHOID INFLAMMATION (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are not diagnostic as only 3 hair follicles are present for evaluation, and no deep dermis or subcutis (where assessment for the peribulbar inflammation typically of inflammatory stage alopecia areata is done). Pigment casts can be seen in a variety of different settings, including alopecia areata, traction alopecia, pressure-induced alopecia, and trichotillomania. The slight perivascular inflammation present is nonspecific. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge of the process could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.   Initial and multiple levels were examined. Sections show 3 hair follicles present for evaluation (1 terminal hair and 2 vellus hairs). There is mild perivascular lymphoid inflammation and focal parakeratosis. The specimen is taken predominantly at the level of the upper reticular dermis and therefore sebaceous glands and follicular bulbs are not present for evaluation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 3/2/2018

벢D18-38142베. Right occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. 벢D18-39270베. Left shin, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LATE STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, connective tissue disease and chronic alopecia areata. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The relative lack of significant lymphoid infiltrate or marked lymphocyte atypia preclude a diagnosis of mycosis fungoides in this specimen. If the lesion has been recently topically treated, histological findings may be suppressed. Because there is minimal lymphoid inflammation, immunochemical or molecular studies are unlikely to be contributory, but they are available upon request.  Because lymphocytic dyscrasias may evolve over time, mimicking dermatitis in early stages, continued clinical observation and additional sampling over time may be appropriate.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%%3/8/2018
벢D18-39769베. Left superior central forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.  Approximately 12 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Left lateral forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. Comment: Please refer to part A for detailed explanation. 3/9/2018

벢D18-46413베. Mid frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.   Initial and multiple levels were examined. Approximately 17 hair follicle are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased (terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 3.5:1), and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits. 벢D18-48692베. Posterior scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ACNE KELOIDALIS NUCHAE IN THE APPROPRIATE CLINICAL SETTING.  Comment: Acne keloidalis (AK) shares some histopathologic findings that are similar to central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA) and it is not uncommon for AK and CCCA to be found in association with each other. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show cystically dilated hair follicles associated with perifollicular concentric and dermal fibrosis with associated naked hair shafts with foreign body giant cell reaction. There is a mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate and the sebaceous glands are diminished.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). An AFB stain is negative. However, special stains are not sensitive.  Cultures of tissue are recommended if infection is a clinical concern. This case was reviewed by Dr. Elsa Velazquez who concurs with the above interpretation. Case discussed with and results communicated to Dr. Golubets by phone on 3/22/2018.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%akn%% 3/23/2018
벢D18-49101베. Posterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS IN THE APPROPRIATE CLINICAL SETTING.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyperkeratosis. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%% 3/23/2018

벢D18-49531베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The presence of miniaturized hair follicles supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, while the decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  Interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Sections show a decrease in terminal follicle density, without evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. Miniaturized hair follicles are appreciated with a a few catagen/telogen follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagac%% 3/23/2018

벢D18-49914베. Left parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NONSCARRING ALOPECIA WITH INCREASE IN MINIATURIZED HAIRS, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: There is a marked increase in miniaturized hairs, which is consistent with androgenetic alopecia. Given the patchy nature of the hair loss clinically, consideration was also given to alopecia areata (as miniaturization is also a feature of this disorder); however, in alopecia areata there is also an increase in catagen/telogen hairs and often residual peribulbar inflammation, neither of which are present in this biopsy, precluding that diagnosis in this biopsy. Since the clinical and histologic findings seem somewhat incongruous, clinical correlation is recommended to ensure that the biopsy is representative of the underlying clinical disorder, particular as interpretation is somewhat limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present for evaluation. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Initial and multiple levels were examined. Approximately 18 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits (approximately 16 percent). There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of < 1:1. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungal hyphae). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 3/23/2018

Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury is lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While differentiation between these two processes can be difficult on biopsies which do not a significant number of hair follicles for evaluation (such as this one) and therefore lichen planopilaris cannot be entirely excluded,  the presence of interfollicular interface injury and increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, favor the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy. 벢D18-55106베. Left parietal area scalp, Shave:%%P%% SURFACE OF A RUPTURED SUPPURATIVE FOLLICULITIS WITH ACUTE AND CHRONIC INFLAMMATION. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.   The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.    Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits. 벢D18-57545베. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%%4/6/2018

벢D18-58433베. Right inferior hair swirl, Punch biopsy: %%P%% TUFTED FOLLICULITIS (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).   Comment:  The histological features are dominated by marked polytrichia. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  So called "tufted folliculitis" is a late stage process most commonly resulting from central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia in both Caucasian and non-Caucasian patients. It can occasionally be seen in a wide variety of disorders, including dissecting cellulitis, acne keloidalis nuchae and myriad other causes of scarring alopecia. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. Left antihelix at 3:00, Punch biopsy: %%P%% HYPERTROPHIC ACTINIC KERATOSIS; EXTENDING TO THE SIDE AND DEEP TISSUE EDGES.  Comment:   Sections show acanthosis, atypical squamous cells in the lower epidermis and overlying parakeratosis. There is also folliculitis, with perifollicular inflammation and granulation tissue. The lesion is partly transected and therefore its base cannot be fully evaluated. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%hak%% 4/5/2018

벢D18-60505베. Left occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% B. Mid-occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA WITH RUPTURED FOLLICULITIS (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis early stage of folliculitis decalvans versus an inflammatory alopecia such as lichen planopilaris. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.   %%88305%%%%lmsai%% 4/11/2018

There is mild spongiosis of the overlying epidermis, consistent with a superimposed eczematous dermatitis (such as contact dermatitis or seborrheic dermatitis). 벢D18-64532베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and mild increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases. As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.  . There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation. 4/16/2018

Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 4/25/2018
벢D18-71156베. Right lateral forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EARLY LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus,  some hair follicles demonstrate  interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. Scarring alopecia is not noted . 벢D18-71376베. Right superior medial forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with mild perifollicular fibrosis, miniturization, with slightly increased telogen hairs and the suggestion of traumatized hair follicles favoring traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques, or chronic hair plucking.  Clinical correlation is advised, particularly given the subtle nature of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include early androgenetic alopecia. This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.    The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased and there is the suggestion of traumatized hair follicles with follicular miniaturization. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ftr%%  B. 벢D18-74634베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.  Approximately 16 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%4/30/2018

벢D18-75842베. Left A vertex scalp L frontal parietal vertex scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA CONSISTENT WITH LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. 벢D18-76066베. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% RUPTURED SUPPURATIVE FOLLICULITIS, CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: Features characteristic of lupus erythematosus and lichen planopilaris are not identified. The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Additional sampling from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.    Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%%5/2/2018
벢D18-76073베. Left scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  There is no evidence of significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. There is focal perifollicular fibrosis. The latter finding is favored to be an incidental finding due to resolving folliculitis. However, if there is a clinical suspicion for scarring alopecia, a repeat 4 mm punch biopsy from the advancing edge of the process is recommended.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% This case was reviewed by Dr. Marier Hernandez who concurs with the above interpretation.  5/2/2018

벢D18-76315베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: Features diagnostic of lupus erythematosus are not identified. The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Elsa Velazquez who concurs with the above interpretation.   Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%  B. Right superior posterior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCALP TISSUE WITH MILD MINIATURIZATION. %%88305%%%%freetext%% %%88312%%  Comment: No histologic features of alopecia areata or lichen planopilaris are identified. The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (4) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. Comment: This is a difficult biopsy to interpret, with conflicting findings. Several studies have demonstrated that there are no reliable histologic, immunophenotypic, or even molecular studies to definitively distinguish between idiopathic follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa) and follicular mucinosis associated with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and the findings in this biopsy would be consistent with either, in the appropriate clinical context. Sections demonstrate a fragment of scalp epithelium with miniaturization, prominent sebaceous gland and a mild increase in telogen / catagen hair follicles. The findings are subtle but are consistent with early androgenetic alopecia.  Although the increased telogen / catagens are less than 15% of hair follicles, an associated resolving telogen effluvium cannot be excluded. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%5/7/2018
벢D18-80231베. Left superior central forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and subtle patchy interface injury with a sparse lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain shows incidental pityrosporum yeast in a hair follicle. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%% 5/7/2018
벢D18-80318베. Crown of scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   Sections show scarring alopecia with perifollicular fibrosis, patchy lymphocytic infiltrates without interface changes, and asymmetric thinning of the follicular epithelium. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca1%%5/8/2018

Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy. 벢D18-83708베. Right crown, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased and there is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 5/14/2018
벢D18-83773베. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FRAGMENT OF SCALP WITH NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA AND PERIFOLLICULAR INFLAMMATION.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle. There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. There is mild miniaturization with perifollicular inflammation/fibrosis. Premature loss of inner root sheath is focally present. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  Characteristic features of seborrheic dermatitis are not seen. Although the classical features of lichen planopilaris are not seen, due to present of perifollicular inflammation and clinical suspicion, the differential diagnosis includes early lichen planopilaris. A consideration was also given to early stages of central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, however this diagnosis is less likely in this clinical setting. This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 5/14/2018

벢D18-85347베. Left frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury and increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyerkeratosis. There is also a subtle increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation which shows basement membrane thickening (and is negative for fungus). 벢D18-87688베. Right scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. Scarring is absent. Pigment cast are seen within some of the hair follicles, suggestive of a compoennt of chronic traction. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.   Sections shows no significant decrease in follicle density and no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. 벢D18-88288베. Right mid scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The presence of miniaturized hair follicles with a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, while the decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion and some follicle units with retained sebaceous glands that lack terminal hairs, suggests superimposed chronic traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  Interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Sections show a decrease in terminal follicle density, without evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. Miniaturized hair follicles are appreciated with a slight increase in the percentage of catagen/telogen follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagac%%5/17/2018

벢D18-92195베. Posterior mid parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA. 벢D18-93856베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.    At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. 벢D18-105740베. Right occipital scalp, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH A COMPONENT OF EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: Initial and level sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density, and there are miniaturized follicles. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There is dermal fibrosis, which may reflect the chronicity of the process, but features of scarring alopecia are not identified. There are increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase, consistent with a component of effluvium. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are Demodex mites, bacteria, and few Pityrosporum yeasts within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. Clinical notes and photo were reviewed, and are appreciated. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 6/12/2018
벢D18-105982베. Right medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ALOPECIA AREATA. 벢D18-107714베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 6/12/2018

벢D18-109201베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH FEATURES OF CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment:  Sections show prominent concentric perifollicular fibrosis with focal low-density follicular epithelial interface inflammation and evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. There is also eccentric epithelial atrophy with focal early desquamation. This pattern may be associated with chronic traction, including secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania). Late lesions of frontal fibrosing alopecia may also show similar changes. The percentage of catagen/telogen follicles is increased, and a component of concurrent telogen effluvium is possible. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벢D18-109913베. Right parietal scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and few residual sebaceous glands, consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. Interface epidermal changes are not identified. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are numerous bacteria within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungi. In addition, there is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus, cicatricial fibrosis, and residual fibrous tracts. These changes are consistent with scarring alopecia, and the differential diagnosis would include lichen planopilaris, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, or, less likely but possible, lupus erythematosus. Clinical correlation is needed to differentiate them. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 6/15/2018
