벢D18-113096베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). Section show increased catagen/telogen hairs in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 6/18/2018

벢D18-113367베. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: There is suppurative folliculitis.  The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as acne keloidalis.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation and is negative for fungus. This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%%6/19/2018

벢D18-114021베. Left scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for these findings includes central centrifugal scarring alopecia and lichen planopilaris. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. While the perifollicular fibrosis and asymmetric thinning of the follicular epithelium favors central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, a few follicles at the level of the infundibulum show interface injury, suggestive of lichen planopilaris.  Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  This case was reviewed at dermatopathology case conference.  %%88305%%%%lmsa%%%%88312%%   B. Right scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment). 벢D18-116827베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% MILD FOLLICULITIS AND PERIFOLLICULITIS PLEASE SEE THE COMMENT. Interpretation is limited due to the small number of follicular units present for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. 벢D18-118229베. Left superior medial midback, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% JUNCTIONAL NEVUS WITH ARCHITECTURAL DISORDER AND MILD CYTOLOGIC ATYPIA (DYSPLASTIC NEVUS); THE EXAMINED MARGINS ARE NOT INVOLVED. %%88305%%%%jnmild%%  B. Left lateral upper back, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% LENTIGINOUS JUNCTIONAL NEVUS. %%88305%%%%ljn%%  C. Superior mid forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EDGE OF SCALP BIOPSY WITH ACTINIC DAMAGE (please see comment).  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are essentially within normal limits for the anatomic site, without evidence of a significant increase in miniaturized or telogen hairs, inflammation, or scarring. The lack of significant histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia may be due to an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission), very early androgenetic alopecia with subthreshold diagnostic findings, or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  In addition, frontal fibrosing alopecia can be very focal and changes can therefore be absent on histologic review.  Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, additional punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered, if clinically indicated.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. 벢D18-118843베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Seth Rosenthal and Dr. Mei-Yu Hsu who concur with the above interpretation.   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). A T. pallidum immunostain was performed, which is negative for spirochetal organisms. Kappa and lambda stain sections exhibit a polyclonal plasma cell population. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%6/27/2018

벢D18-121161베. Left vertex scalp, Punch biopsy 4 mm:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment:The limited degree of perifollicular fibrosis and lack of sinus tract formation militate against dissecting cellulitis.  The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Additional sampling from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. This case was reviewed by Dr. Alejandro Soler who concurs with the above interpretation.     Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 6/28/2018
벢D18-121913베. Right medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CHANGES MOST SUGGESTIVE OF PSORIATIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: An increase in catagen/telogen hairs, increase in miniaturized hairs, and presence of a superficial and deep perivascular and perifollicular lymphoid infiltrate in the absence of significant follicular destruction, are the features that have been described in alopecia associated with psoriasis. The lack of follicular destruction is against a scarring alopecia such as central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia or lichen planopilaris.   Initial and multiple levels were examined. Sections from both biopsies show psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with foci of parakeratosis containing neutrophils (best seen in biopsy B), associated with a superficial perivascular and deep perifollicular lymphoid infiltrate with numerous plasma cells.  There is an increase in catagen/telogen (20 %) and miniaturized hairs, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 1:3 in biopsy B, and approximately 3:1 in biopsy A. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain, in either biopsy. T. pallidum immunostains were performed fro completeness sake (given the number of plasma cells present), which are negative for spirochetal organisms in both biopsies.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%psalo%%  B. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CHANGES MOST SUGGESTIVE OF PSORIATIC ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%psalo%% 7/3/2018

벢D18-123921베. Left scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Although the findings are very subtle, there is overall decrease in follicular density associated with concentric fibroplasia and focal patchy interface injury with lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, suggestive of lichen planopilaris. No interfollicular interface injury, increase in dermal mucin, or deep perifollicular inflammation or perivascular inflammation as expected in lupus is seen. Diagnostic features of alopecia areata are no seen. Interpretation is limited due to the small number of follicular units present for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis.  As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). 벢D18-124849베. Right lower cutaneous lip, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ALOPECIA AREATA, WITH SUPERIMPOSED ECZEMATOUS DERMATITIS.  Comment:   Sections show follicular miniaturization with a modest catagen-telogen shift. While not definitive, these findings in conjunction with the clinical appearance of the lesion are most consistent with alopecia areata. There is no evidence of scarring. There is also follicular epidermal spongiosis and the periodic acid-Schiff stain shows pityrosporum yeast in the stratum corneum, suggestive of a superimposed eczematous or allergic contact dermatitis, or possibly a pityrosporum folliculitis. Although mucinosis is not identified with an alcian blue stain, due to the presence of focal follicular exocytosis of the infiltrate, immunohistichemical stains were performed, which show a non-diagnostic pattern, with variable CD3, CD4 and CD8 expression throughout several levels of the biopsy; however, procurement of levels is limited by the Headington processing technique for alopecia. The H&E and immunophenotypic findings support a reactive process; Since very early stages of cutaneous T-cell dyscrasia can mimic spongiotic dermatitis histologically, however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended, particularly if clinical progression occurs despite conservative therapeutic measures, and/or if the patient has been recently applying topical therapy (as this can affect the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings). This case was reviewed by Drs. Adriano Piris and Christopher Dowling who concur with the above interpretation. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aa%% 7/3/2018

벢D18-127572베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia.  Although the former is favored, differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. 벢D18-128872베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS AND CONCURRENT ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. There is also marked follicular miniaturization consistent with concurrent androgenetic alopecia.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 7/9/2018
벢P18-321베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy (S18-602 A1-A2, Skin Dermatology & Aesthetics, 2/7/18):%%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The lack of well-developed interface injury, in combination with the presence of eccentric follicular epithelium thinning, all support the differential diagnosis of central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia in this clinical context. The submitted clinical image is reviewed (and is appreciated).  Microscopic Description: Initial and multiple additional levels (performed in our laboratory) were examined. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands in the affected follicular units. Many of the follicles in the affected follicular units demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis shows acanthosis but is otherwise essentially unremarkable.  %%ccca%%2/22/2018
벢P18-638베. Frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH TRICHOTILLOMANIA.  Comment:  Sections demonstrate a fragment of scalp tissue with a significant increase in telogen / catagen hair follicles (approximately 90%).  In addition, hair casts and traumatized hair follicles are noted. A significant shift to telogen / catagen hair follicles can be seen in alopecia areata, trichotillomania and pressure induced alopecia.  The findings are non-specific and both alopecia areata and trichotillomania are clinically considered, however, given the presence of fat necrosis ,  significant nu,ber of pigment casts and traumatized hair follicles, trichotillomania is favored. Miniaturization is also noted. This may represent associated androgenetic alopecia.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ttm%%5/31/2018
벢P18-705베. Left cheek of the face, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% SEBORRHEIC KERATOSIS, IRRITATED AND INFLAMED WITH MUCIN DEPOSITION.  Comment:   Given the mucin deposition (highlighted with an Alcian blue stain) alopecia mucinosa was considered; however, the presence of a keratosis with marked inflammation favors a reactive process. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Sections show papillary epithelial hyperplasia with hyperkeratosis, and basal cell layer hyperpigmentation. An inflammatory cell infiltrate, parakeratosis and crust are present. Lymphoid infiltrate shows a mixed staining with CD3 and CD20. Initial and level sections were examined. This case was reviewed by Dr. Julie Reimann who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%skii%%5/30/2018
벢P18-801베. Left superior frontal scalp, Punch biopsy (DA8826359, Abington Derm Associates, 4/20/18):%%P%%  MINIATURIZED HAIR FOLLICLES WITH A DECREASED IN NUMBER OF FOLLICULAR UNITS, (Please See Comment).  Comment: Additional findings include slight non-specific chronic inflammation with pigment incontinence. In the right clinical setting the changes are compatible with androgenetic alopecia. However, for an accurate evaluation of the underlying process  (in a patient with "hair loss") further sampling to be processed using the Headington technique is recommended.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%7/5/2018
벢X17-73299베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, FAVOR EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).There are no definitive  changes of traction alopecia. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%   B. 벢X18-170베. Left frontal scalp, anterior, Punch biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris, and lupus erythematosus. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Direct immunofluorescence may be helpful in further evaluation of this process, if clinically indicated.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%%  B. 벢X18-173베. Scalp:%%P%% SHAVE BIOPSY CONSISTENT WITH NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA, CLINICALLY MOST COMPATIBLE WITH ALOPECIA AREATA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. There are few melanophages in the papillary dermis, consistent with pigment incontinence, and Demodex mites in a follicular ostia. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Case was discussed with Dr. Wolfe. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 1/5/2018

While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy. 벢X18-901베. Right frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA; FAVOR CENTRAL CENTRIGUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA. Right frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a mild lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles, and focal granulomatous inflammation secondary to a ruptured follicle. 벢X18-1483베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED COMPLEX ALOPECIA WITH SCARRING FEATURES.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts, which may represent a background of androgenetic alopecia. The sebaceous glands are partially preserved. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. In addition, there is superficial dermal cicatricial fibrosis and perifollicular fibroplasia, consistent with scarring alopecia. Although advanced androgenetic alopecia may show cicatricial fibrosis, a primary scarring alopecia in a background of androgenetic alopecia cannot be ruled out. The differential diagnosis would include lichen planopilaris, central centrifugal alopecia, or, less likely, lupus erythematosus. Clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical consideration. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility.   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsa%% 1/14/2018

벢X18-1727베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: While the findings in the biopsy are subtle and the percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is not significantly increased, in the resolving phase of telogen effluvium the biopsy findings are essentially within normal limits, and therefore these findings are consistent with resolving telogen effluvium in this clinical context.  There is a very slight decrease in terminal hair follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio and percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%rte%%  B. Mid occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show early miniaturization and a mild increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Approximately 46 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is slighly increased, but within normal limits. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of appoximately 7:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 1/15/2018
벢X18-1846베. Left parietal scalp, Punch biopsy 4 mm:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH A COMPONENT OF EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is mild decrease in follicular density and the sebaceous glands are preserved. Scarring fibrosis is not identified. There are miniaturized follicles.  There are also empty shafts, which may represent a component of effluvium. There is minimal chronic inflammation. Peribulbar inflammation or acute inflammation is not identified. There are numerous bacteria within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungi. Androgenetic alopecia is favored over alopecia areata, but clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%  B. 벢X18-2263베. Posterior mid-parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ADVANCED ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA, CANNOT RULE OUT EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. There are only few residual sebaceous glands. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. Pityrosporum yeasts or Demodex mites are not identified. There is incipient scarring fibrosis of the superficial dermis. Although an advanced androgenetic alopecia with incipient fibrosis is favored, early scarring alopecia, including central centrifugal alopecia cannot be completely ruled out. Clinical notes and photo were reviewed, and are appreciated. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 1/17/2018
벢X18-2540베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: There are mild perifollicular interface changes favoring lichen planopilaris over central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia in this biopsy specimen. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and minimal interfollicular interface injury with mild increased in increase in dermal mucin. There is focal granulomatous inflammation surrounding some follicles. Direct immunofluorescence may be helpful in further evaluation of this process, if clinically indicated. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Alejandro Soler who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%   B. Superior mid forehead, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% HYPERTROPHIC ACTINIC KERATOSIS. 벢X18-2599베. Vertex scalp:%%P%% COMPLEX ALOPECIA WITH SCARRING FEATURES.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. The sebaceous glands are partially preserved. There are distorted follicles with few pigment casts. There are also ruptured follicles with keratin granulomas, and follicles with perifollicular fibroplasia and surrounding patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The changes are complex. There is a background of androgenetic alopecia and a component of traction. In addition there are features of incipient scarring alopecia, and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia or lichen planopilaris can be considered. Clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 1/18/2018
벢X18-2643베. Right scalp, Punch: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris and lupus, favor central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia in this case. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. Incidental osteoma cutis is noted. 벢X18-2699베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 1/18/2018
벢X18-2804베. Left superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with focal intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. There is surrounding chronic inflammation with numerous plasma cells and cicatricial fibrosis. PAS stain is negative for fungi. A folliculitis decalvans pattern can be seen in scarring alopecia of different types, such as central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, syphilis, and discoid lupus. Clinical correlation is needed to determine if those may be etiologies of this inflamed scarring alopecia. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 1/18/2018
벢X18-3191베. Right frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%  B. Posterior scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a mild lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles, and focal acute inflammation. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 1/24/2018
벢X18-3204베. Frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings favor end stage central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia in this patient. The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia/ lichen planopilaris, and also lupus erythematosus. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. Incidental small focus of osteoma cutis is noted. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Direct immunofluorescence may be helpful in further evaluation of this process, if clinically indicated. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 1/22/2018
벢X18-3391베. Vertical scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level vertical sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There is partial preservation of the sebaceous glands, which may reflect the edge between alopecia and a less affected area. There is cicatricial fibrosis and perifollicular hyalinization of the collagen. There is no significant inflammation. PAS stain is negative for fungi. There are distorted follicles and a component of traction cannot be ruled out. Pigment casts are not identified. The changes are consistent with a scarring alopecia, and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is favored, but clinical correlation is needed to support this diagnosis. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. Horizontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. The changes are similar to the accompanying biopsy. PAS stain is negative for fungi. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%1/23/2018
벢X18-3452베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a marked decrease in follicular density. There is cicatricial fibrosis, perifollicular fibroplasia, and loss of sebaceous glands. There is perifollicular chronic and acute inflammation. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The differential diagnosis includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris, or, less likely but possible, lupus erythematosus. Clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical consideration. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 1/24/2018
벢X18-3545베. Vertex scalp, Punch: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris, and lupus erythematosus. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Direct immunofluorescence may be helpful in further evaluation of this process, if clinically indicated. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 1/23/2018
벢X18-3546베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with slightly increased telogen hairs and the suggestion of traumatized hair follicles favoring early traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques, or chronic hair plucking. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process and miniaturization is absent. Clinical correlation is advised, particularly given the subtle nature of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, additional punch biopsy, preferably 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered, if clinically indicated.  Approximately 11 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is slightly increased and there is the suggestion of traumatized hair follicles. Definitive miniaturization is not seen. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ftr%% 1/23/2018
벢X18-3547베. Posterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH MILD ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND EFFLUVIUM; CANNOT RULE OUT OUT EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. The changes are complex. There is a mild to moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia, and empty shafts, which may represent effluvium. There is a single pigment cast, suggestive of a component of traction. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are bacteria within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungi. There are superficial changes consistent with mild lichen simplex chronicus. There is also mild cicatricial fibrosis of the superficial dermis, and incipient scarring alopecia cannot be ruled out. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 1/24/2018

If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis. 벢X18-3643베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% MILD ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND PUSTULAR FOLLICULITIS.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a mild decrease in follicular density, and few miniaturized follicles are present. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There are also empty shafts, which may represent a component of effluvium. In addition there is pustular folliculitis, and some of the inflamed follicles are ruptured, with surrounding abscess formation. There are numerous bacteria and Pityrosporum yeasts within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. Although scarring alopecia is not identified in this biopsy, incipient folliculitis decalvans cannot be completely ruled out.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 1/24/2018

벢X18-4022베. Mid parietal scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate decrease in follicular density. There is partial loss of the sebaceous glands, perifollicular fibroplasia, fused follicles, few ruptured follicles, early scarring fibrosis of the superficial dermis, and patchy chronic inflammation. In addition there are few miniaturized follicles, which may represent a background of androgenetic alopecia. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The differential diagnosis includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris, or, less likely, lupus erythematosus. Clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. Ancillary studies may be prudent if lupus erythematosus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 1/26/2018
벢X18-4074베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, mild interface injury with a perifollicular lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%%  B. Right anterior scalp, Punch: %%P%% ALOPECIA, NOS. 벢X18-4700베. Hair, Punch biopsy: %%P%% MILD DECREASE IN FOLLICULAR DENSITY.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a mild decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase. There are also empty shafts, which may represent a component of effluvium. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation, plasma cells, or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are numerous Pityrosporum yeasts and bacteria within the superficial portion of the hair follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. The changes may represent early androgenetic alopecia. The case was discussed with Dr. Nowicky on 1/31/18. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%alo%% 1/31/2018
벢X18-4734베. Scalp vertical, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Initial and level vertical sections were examined. There is a severe decrease in follicular density. There is perifollicular fibroplasia, fused follicles, loss of sebaceous glands, scarring fibrosis and patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi, and shows preservation of the epidermal basement membrane. Lichen planopilaris is favored over lupus erythematosus or central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. However, clinical correlation is needed to differentiate them. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is still a clinical possibility.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%  B. 벢X18-5113베. Right occipital scalp, Punch: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH CHANGES SECONDARY TO EXTERNAL IRRITATION.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There is patchy chronic inflammation and some of the follicles are fused, with incipient perifollicular fibroplasia. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are numerous bacteria and Pityrosporum yeasts. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. The changes are suggestive of a chronic non-scarring alopecia. A clinical photo was reviewed, and is appreciated. Given the clinical alopecia areata with changes secondary to external irritation can be considered. However, early scarring alopecia cannot be completely ruled out. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%alo%%  B. 벢X18-6229베. Frontal scalp, Punch biopsy 4 mm:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND EFFLUVIUM, CANNOT RULE OUT EARLY LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a mild to moderate decrease in follicular density and there are miniaturized follicles, consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. There are also empty shafts, and a component of effluvium can be considered. The sebaceous glands are preserved. In addition, there are fused follicles and incipient perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus, and an incipient scarring alopecia, such as lichen planopilaris, including the frontal fibrosing variant, cannot be completely ruled out. Peribulbar inflammation or acute inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. Tests to measure serum levels of hormones and metabolites may be helpful, if an underlying hormonal or nutritional imbalance is a clinical possibility. The case was discussed with Dr. McClellan on 2/8/18. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 2/8/2018
벢X18-6444베. Left temple, Punch: %%P%% EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA, SUGGESTIVE OF CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis could include late traction alopecia with scarring, and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. At the level of the isthmus, there is focal disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a mild lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. Left temple, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy may be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  There is a decrease in terminal follicle density, with focal suggestion of early scarring and no significant inflammation. The epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. No significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles is appreciated. The percentage of catagen/telogen follicles is increased. 벢X18-6449베. Frontal crown of scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a chronic lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. Acute inflammation is not noted. The differential diagnosis could include late stage of lichen planopilaris/frontal fibrosing alopecia. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.This case was reviewed by Dr. Alejandro Soler who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 2/9/2018
벢X18-6625베. Frontal hairline, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%%  B. Left sideburn, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%lmsa%% 2/8/2018
벢X18-6632베. Left superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Approximately 19 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 2:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Left superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present for evaluation in vertical sections, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, or resolving telogen effluvium. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 2/8/2018

벢X18-8611베. Left superior medial forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 2/20/2018

Peribulbar lymphocytic inflammation is appreciated, and there is an increase in catagen/telogen hairs. There is also a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles), with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 2:1. There is no evidence of scarring, and the epidermis is unremarkable. 벢X18-11294베. Right frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/7/2018
벢X18-11393베. Right anterior hairline; Punch:%%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA IN A BACKGROUND OF ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles, partial preservation of the sebaceous glands, and residual fibrous tracts. These changes are consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. In addition, there are ruptured follicles with surrounding keratin granulomas, perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus, and incipient scarring fibrosis. These changes are consistent with scarring alopecia and the differential diagnosis would include central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia and lichen planopilaris. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are Demodex mites within the superficial portion of the hair follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungi.   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 3/8/2018

벢X18-14624베. Center scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for inflamed scarring alopecia could include central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia with marked inflammation, and lupus erythematosus. The lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. There is focal granulomatous inflammation secondary to a ruptured follicle. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 3/23/2018

벢X18-14837베. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%%  B. Left inferior posterior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 3/26/2018

벢X18-15786베. Scalp vertex 1, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are minimal, may be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing) in a background of early androgenetic alopecia. There is a mild decrease in terminal follicle density, with minimal scarring, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is some evidence of mild follicular distortion and trauma. No significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles is appreciated. The percentage of catagen/telogen follicles is slightly increased. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%trac%%  B. Scalp vertex 2, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: There are features of early androgenetic alopecia in the background. The findings are focal and mild, could be secondary to traction of grooming techniques, however a component of early central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia cannot be entirely excluded. At the level of the isthmus, there is mild disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 3/30/2018
벢X18-15953베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent, however there is mild perifollicular chronic inflammation in the superficial dermis with mild perifollicular fibrosis, could be artifactual. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/30/2018
벢X18-16091베. Left temple scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level sections were examined. There is a severe decrease in follicular density. There is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus and dermal cicatricial fibrosis. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. There are few residual miniaturized follicles and rare sebaceous glands. There is minimal chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are few Pityrosporum yeasts in the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. The changes are consistent with scarring alopecia, and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is favored over lichen planopilaris or lupus erythematosus. Clinical correlation is needed. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 4/3/2018
벢X18-16264베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, FAVOR CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are few residual sebaceous glands. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts, which may represent a background of androgenetic alopecia. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi, and shows preserved epidermal basement membrane. In addition there is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus, superficial scarring fibrosis, and patchy chronic inflammation, consistent with scarring alopecia. Central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is favored, but lichen planopilaris, or, less likely, lupus erythematosus, can be considered.  Ancillary studies may be prudent if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca1%%4/2/2018
벢X18-16324베. Mid occipital scalp, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The biopsy is superficial. The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Additional sampling from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 4/2/2018
벢X18-16356베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. The sebaceous glands are decreased. There is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus and patchy surrounding chronic inflammation. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation are not identified. There are bacteria and Pityrosporum yeasts within the superficial portion of the follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. The differential diagnosis includes lichen planopilaris, or the frontal fibrosing variant, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, or, less likely, lupus erythematosus. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsai%%  B. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. The changes are similar to the accompanying biopsy. PAS stain is negative for fungal hyphae. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsai%% 4/3/2018
벢X18-16360베. Right parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED SCARRING ALOPECIA, FAVOR CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a severe decrease in follicular density and the sebaceous glands are lost. There is fusion of follicles and perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus. There is hyperplasia of sweat glands. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The changes are consistent with advanced scarring alopecia. Central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is favored. However, lichen planopilaris or, less likely, lupus erythematosus, can also be considered. Clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them, and ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 4/3/2018

벢X18-16914베. Vertex scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% COMPLEX ALOPECIA WITH CHANGES SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY SCARRING.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a mild to moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts, consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. The sebaceous glands are mostly preserved. There are also increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase, which may represent a component of effluvium. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The epidermal basement membrane is preserved. In addition, there is fusion of the superficial portion of the follicles and perifollicular fibroplasia, suggesting early scarring alopecia, and incipient central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia is favored.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%alo%% 4/5/2018
벢X18-16999베. Right parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH EARLY SCARRING.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. The sebaceous glands are mostly preserved. These changes are consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. There are also empty shafts, which may represent a component of effluvium. In addition, there is fusion of the superficial portion of the hair follicles and superficial dermal fibrosis, consistent with early scarring alopecia. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. There is patchy chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are numerous bacteria within the superficial portion of the hair follicles. PAS stain is negative for fungi. 벢X18-17302베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF ALOPECIA AREATA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate to severe decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts, and there are increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase. The sebaceous glands are preserved. There is perivascular chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. Although peribulbar inflammation is not seen, the changes favor alopecia areata over androgenetic alopecia, but clinical correlation is needed to distinguish them. Interface epidermal changes are not seen, and plasma cells are not identified. However, in light of the clinical, ancillary tests to rule out an underlying collagen vascular disease, and an RPR test may be prudent, if clinically indicated. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aa%% 4/10/2018

벢X18-17725베. Posterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%%  B. Left frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS. 벢X18-18006베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The differential diagnosis for this lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lupus erythematosus (favored) and lichen planopilaris. The presence of follicular plugging, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, the hair follicles present demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic anf granulomatous infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the involved follicles.  There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus or basement membrane thickening).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%%  B. Left lateral frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The differential diagnosis for this lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lupus erythematosus (favored) and lichen planopilaris. The presence of follicular plugging, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, the hair follicles present demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic anf granulomatous infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the involved follicles.  There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus or basement membrane thickening).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%% 4/12/2018
벢X18-18299베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.   Comment:  The findings in this biopsy are unusual and difficult to correlate clinically.  While the differential diagnosis for this scarring alopecia includes tinea capitis, no fungi are detected with multiple periodic acid-Schiff and GMS stains performed on multiple levels.  Other considerations, although the histology is not typical, could include traction alopecia and lupus erythematosus.  Additionally, there are some histologic features of central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia and lichen planopilaris, although the demographics would be unusual in this case.  The unusual histology and advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process.  An sdditional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. Multiple small to intermediate size free hair shafts with associated giant cell reaction are present in the dermis and subcutis.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 4/25/2018
벢X18-18415베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH BACKGROUND OF ALOPECIA AREATA AND NUMEROUS DEMODEX MITES WITHIN THE HAIR FOLLICLES.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. There are also increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase. Although peribulbar inflammation is not identified, the changes are consistent with a background of alopecia areata. There are numerous Demodex mites within the superficial portion of the follicles, and surrounding chronic and acute inflammation. There is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus, which may be secondary to external irritation. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The case was discussed with PA Antonella Viterbo on 4/18/18. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aa%% 4/18/2018
벢X18-18742베. Right temple, Punch: %%P%% COMPLEX NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tracts. The sebaceous glands are mostly preserved. There are markedly increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase. There is also a rare pigment cast. There is minimal chronic inflammation. Acute inflammation or peribulbar inflammation is not identified. There are numerous bacteria within the superficial portion of the follicles. Epidermal interface changes are not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The changes are complex and favor a non-scarring alopecia. Although androgenetic alopecia with a component of effluvium can be considered, because of the marked increase in follicles in catagen/telogen phase, diffuse alopecia areata cannot be ruled out. The pigment cast is suggestive of a component of traction. Typical changes of lichen planopilaris, or the frontal fibrosing variant are not identified.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%alo%%  B. There is a severe decrease in follicular density, and only few residual sebaceous glands.
