벢X18-19202베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTIC INFLAMMATORY NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment: Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined. A PAS stain (with appropriate controls) is negative for fungal hyphae. There is a mild perivascular and perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate with foci showing lymphocytes and rare eosinophils in the retained vascular stellae of some miniaturized hairs. A slight increase in telogen hairs is seen in addition to a slight increase in miniaturized hairs. Scarring is not seen. Given the few foci showing occasional eosinophils with some lymphocytes in vascular stellae, a subtle alopecia areata is favored over other causes of non-scarring alopecia such as telogen effluvium or androgenetic alopecia (see Elston DM, et al., in JAAD, 1997; 37:101-6). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aa%% 4/20/2018
벢X18-20203베. Inferior mid forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA AND VITILIGO.  Comment: Initial and level sections were examined. Sections show loss of basal layer pigmentation and absence of melanocytes, consistent with vitiligo. There are no hair follicles. There are residual fibrous tracts, dermal atrophy with fibrosis, and increased sweat glands. There is no significant inflammation. PAS stain is negative for fungi. The etiology of the alopecia cannot be determined with certainty because of the advanced stage of the process. Lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus or central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia can be considered. Ancillary studies may be prudent if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 4/25/2018
벢X18-20365베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA.   Comment: At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. Multiple small to intermediate size free hair shafts with associated giant cell reaction and pigment incontinence are present in the dermis and subcutis. Periodic acid-Schiff stain is negative for fungal infection. Additional periodic acid-Schiff stain is in progress and the results will be reported as an addendum. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%%   B. Left superior medial forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis, naked hair shafts and complete absence of folliculosebaceous units. Active inflammation and features of lichen planopilaris or lupus erythematosus alopecia are not seen. Periodic acid-Schiff stain is negative for fungal infection. Given the clinical history of rash at this location after birth, the differential diagnosis most likely include a scarring alopecia secondary to infection and less likely due to trauma or inflammatory dermatitis. However, the advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional periodic acid-Schiff stain is in progress and the results will be reported as an addendum. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Mandana Mahmoodi who concurs with the above interpretation.   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 4/27/2018
벢X18-20499베. Right parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment:   The differential diagnosis could include lichen planopilaris or central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia.  There is also a slight increase in miniaturized hairs, suggestive of concomitant early androgenetic alopecia.  At the level of the isthmus, there is focal disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with focal fibrosis and slightly decreased sebaceous glands. A few of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and slightly eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a mild perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. There is also a slight increase in miniaturized hairs. 벢X18-20680베. Crown scalp, Punch: %%P%% FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: Initial and level sections were examined. Sections show dense acute and chronic inflammation with small granulomas, focal abscess formation, and cicatricial fibrosis. PAS stain is negative for fungi. A folliculitis decalvans pattern can be seen in cicatricial alopecias, including central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and, less likely, in discoid lupus.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 4/30/2018
벢X18-20708베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% COMPLEX ALOPECIA WITH FEATURES OF EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and level horizontal sections were examined. There is a moderate decrease in follicular density. There are miniaturized follicles and residual fibrous tract, with partial preservation of the sebaceous glands, consistent with a background of androgenetic alopecia. There are also increased follicles in catagen/telogen phase, which may represent effluvium. A component of traction cannot be ruled out. There are Demodex mites and numerous bacteria within the superficial portion of the follicles. Acute inflammation is not identified. PAS stain is negative for fungi. In addition, there is perifollicular fibroplasia at the level of the isthmus and patchy chronic inflammation, consistent with early scarring alopecia. The differential diagnosis for these changes includes lichen planopilaris, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, or, less likely but possible, lupus erythematosus. Ancillary studies are recommended if lupus is a clinical possibility. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%alo%% 4/27/2018
벢X18-20834베. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle. There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are at the upper end of normal limits.  A slight increase in miniaturized hairs and rare features of trichomalacia are present.  Taken together, I favor this to be an early stage of traction alopecia.   The differential diagnosis includes resolving telogen effluvium, or diffuse alopecia areata.   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).     A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벢X18-21672베. Crown of scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. 벣D17-339792베. Right superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% PERIFOLLICULITIS; CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: While a subtle form of lichen planopilaris may give this pattern, the findings are not entirely diagnostic of that entity. Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.   As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show perifollicular sparse lymphocytic inflammation. %%88305%%%%rlp%%1/2/2018

벣D17-339876베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA, see comment.  Comment:   There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 3:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. The histologic findings are consistent with early androgenetic alopecia. Of note, there is a mild increase in catagen/telogen follicles of up to 25 percent. New onset telogen effluvium, or recurrent chronic telogen effluvium, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia. Clinical correlation is advised. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Jonathan Ralston who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%% 1/3/2018

The combination of a marked increase in both miniaturized and catagen/telogen hairs as well as pigment casts is consistent with chronic alopecia areata, as in this stage peribulbar inflammation is typically sparse or absent, as it is in this case. 벣D18-259베. Posterior scalp, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment: Although the differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris the overall histologic findings are most consistent with discoid lupus erythematosus. 벣D18-312베. Right temporal peak, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The presence of miniaturized hair follicles with a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia. A decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion and some follicle units with retained sebaceous glands that lack terminal hairs, suggests superimposed traction alopecia There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. Miniaturized hair follicles are appreciated with a slight increase in the percentage of catagen/telogen follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. 벣D18-442베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment: Sections show early miniaturization with occasional telogen hairs consistent with early androgenetic alopecia. In addition there are foci demonstrating follicular distortion and perifollicular fibrosis supportive of superimposed central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia.   5/10 follicles are affected. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. 벣D18-1255베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EARLY LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with free hair shaft granulomas and includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia and lichen planopilaris. The lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation militate against lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis, eccentric thinning of follicular epithelium, and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate perifollicular fibrosis with a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed at dermatopathology case conference with members of our physician staff.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 1/4/2018
벣D18-1295베. L sup parietal scalp anterior, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. L sup parietal scalp posterior, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment A & B: Both biopsies show similar features. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. There are free hair shafts with an associated giant cell reaction. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus) (performed on both biopsies). 벣D18-1374베. Left temple, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Some admixed foreign dermal pigment consistent with tattoo-like material is also noted and some bacterial cocci colonies are also noted associated with hair follicles. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 1/4/2018
벣D18-2130베. Left superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, lichen planopilaris, and folliculitis decalvans. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process) could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%% 1/5/2018

벣D18-4396베. Mid frontal scalp:%%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy. 벣D18-4587베. Scalp, Shave:%%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Additional sampling from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, loss of mature sebaceous glands, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 1/9/2018

Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91).  While the differential diagnosis of the moderate scarring alopecia present with a moderate reduction in the total number of hairs includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), lichen planopilaris (LPP), and lupus erythematosus (LE), the entities of CCCA and LPP are favored. 벣D18-8253베. Right posterior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The overall findings are consistent with the clinical impression of folliculitis decalvans. The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. 벣D18-8260베. Left posterior vertex, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. 벣D18-11405베. Horizontal, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for the pattern of inflammation and scarring seen in this biopsy  includes lichen planopilaris and central centrifugal scarring alopecia. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions, as is the case in this biopsy. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%lmsa%%  B. 벣D18-11879베. Right inferior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH MIXED INFLAMMATION, MOST CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%%1/18/2018

벣D18-13006베. Anterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (3) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 1/19/2018

벣D18-14715베. Right parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury and increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyperkeratosis. There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%% 1/19/2018

벣D18-18775베. Left frontal hairline, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation. A slight increase in telogen hairs is noted.  Scarring is absent. There is evidence of focal follicular distortion and trauma. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. Given the presence of slightly increased telogen hairs and focal follicular distortion, the possibility of a mild component of superimposed traction alopecia could be considered (such as certain hair styling techniques).  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is only slightly increased.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.   Follicular density = 19 (normal = 20-40 per 4 mm punch) Follicular unit morphology = mostly intact with focal distortion Hairs per follicular unit = ~1.5 (normal = 2-4) Follicular dropout = absent  Sebaceous gland loss = absent Catagen/Telogen hairs = ~11% (normal  = 10%) Miniaturized (vellus) hairs = slight increase Inflammatory infiltrate = absent Inflammatory cell type = N/A Interface inflammation = absent Dermal fibrosis (scarring) = absent Fibrous tracts (stelae) = absent PAS stain = negative for fungi  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%   1/24/2018

Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 1/24/2018
벣D18-18871베. Left temporal peak:%%P%% CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   There are slightly increased numbers of miniaturized hairs, and a superimposed mild component of androgenetic alopecia could be considered.  Approximately 16 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch) with appoximately 8 affected follicles.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with moderate fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. Free hair shaft granulomas are present. Left parietal scalp, Punch 3 mm:%%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (6) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. 벣D18-20512베. Left forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND PROBABLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with probable concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below).  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%1/26/2018
벣D18-20569베. Left inferior postauricular skin, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% PITYROSPORUM FOLLICULITIS.  Comment:   Sections show an inflamed hair follicle containing numerous small yeasts, which are highlighted with a PAS stain. %%88312%%  %%88305%%%%pitf%%  B. Left central occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% MOST CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult. Additional sampling from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material.  There is also reduction in number of intact sebaceous glands. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). These findings support the diagnosis of folliculitis decalvans.   Tissue cultures require specific media or fresh tissue, and cannot be performed on the tissue submitted.    %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 1/27/2018

벣D18-23701베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. Approximately 34 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch).  Approximately 8 telogen and 11 miniaturized hairs are present.  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of appoximately 2:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 1/30/2018

벣D18-24300베. Right forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed at dermatopathology case conference with members of our physician staff.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%% 1/31/2018

벣D18-27413베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. A way to distinguish between the two is to perform paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved area of alopecia (central crown/vertex) and uninvolved scalp (usually occiput), as it can help establish a definite diagnosis of early AGA with or without concomitant TE.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 2/6/2018
벣D18-27427베. Crown of scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 2/5/2018
벣D18-27585베. Right scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 2/5/2018
벣D18-27722베. Right anterior frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated).  The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small size of the biopsy and number of follicular units present (~4) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia (favored), resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio is approximately 1:1 and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are essentially within normal limits. 벣D18-34468베. Left parietotemporal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   There are also mildly increased miniaturized hairs noted, such that a concomitant early androgenetic alopecia is suggested.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. 벣D18-38197베. Right superior central forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The presence of miniaturized hair follicles with a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, while the decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion and some follicle units with retained sebaceous glands that lack terminal hairs, suggests superimposed chronic traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  Interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagac%% The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated).  REFERENCE: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). 2/16/2018

벣D18-39679베. Left scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 2/16/2018

벣D18-43903베. Left scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FAVOR FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The lack of interfollicular interface injury or dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus in the clinical context provided.   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. 벣D18-45043베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. 벣D18-48021베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS, RUBBED.  Comment: There are background features of lichen simplex chronicus. The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury and slightly increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyperkeratosis. There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%% 2/27/2018

벣D18-50439베. Left central frontal scalp, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH INTERFACE INJURY (please see comment).  Comment:  Initial and multiple levels were examined. The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury is lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. Differentiation between these two processes can be difficult on biopsies which do not contain subcutis or a significant number of hair follicles for evaluation, as distinction is based on a variety of factors, including examination of the depth of the inflammation, presence of deep dermal mucin deposition, involvement of interfollicular epithelium, and perivascular extension of inflammation. The lack of deep dermis and subcutis for evaluation in this biopsy therefore precludes definitive categorization. A repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show epidermis and upper dermis. There is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated). %%88312%%  %%88305%%%%lmsai%%3/2/2018

벣D18-54294베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (11) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio and percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 3/5/2018
벣D18-54429베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, SEE COMMENT.  Comment: Given the clinical history the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris is favored; however, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia may show identical features and it cannot be completely ruled out. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who is in concurrence with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsa%% 3/5/2018
벣D18-54800베. Right temple:%%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of increased miniaturized hairs without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the small size and superficial nature of the specimen. Mild background seborrheic dermatitis is noted.  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/9/2018
벣D18-54849베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FEMALE PATTERN HAIR LOSS (ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA).  Comment:  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 2:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A PAS stain highlights scattered yeast forms consistent with Pityrosporum; however, no fungal hyphae are identified. The histologic findings are consistent with androgenetic alopecia. This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore and Dr. Jonathan Ralston who concur with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%agaf%% 3/7/2018
벣D18-54870베. Right Parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Based on the histologic findings, the differential diagnosis for the lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia process includes lichen planopilaris and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and focal follicular dyskeratotic cells are present with an associated lymphocytic infiltrate (14/26 follicles affected). Given the presence of dyskeratotic cells in the clinical context, lichen planopilaris is favored over central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. There is also a slight increase in miniaturized hair follicles (5/26 follicles), which is suggestive of a background process of androgenetic alopecia. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 3/7/2018
벣D18-54881베. Right parietal, Biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. Right temporal peak, Biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: A component of androgenetic alopecia also appears to contribute. The findings in this biopsy may be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  There is a decrease in terminal follicle density, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma and some miniaturization of follicles is noted. The percentage of catagen/telogen follicles is increased. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%trac%% 3/6/2018
벣D18-55119베. Posterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/7/2018

벣D18-56444베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH DEVELOPING LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia, although developing lichen planopilaris is favored. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsa%% 3/8/2018
벣D18-56561베. Right crown of scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris and discoid lupus. Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. Initial and multiple levels were examined. Given the increased number of plasma cells a T. pallidum stain was performed and is negative. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).   This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 3/8/2018

Comment: The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia and lichen planopilaris. The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. Additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. 벣D18-57878베. Right parietal scalp, Skin Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs.  Approximately 30 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch).  Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased (5 miniaturized hairs) and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/9/2018
벣D18-57911베. Parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment:  The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, some of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis (2 of 14 hairs affected), and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 3/8/2018

The characteristic features of discoid lupus erythematosus or alopecia areata were not identified in these sections. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 2.5:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. 벣D18-59567베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FEMALE PATTERN HAIR LOSS (ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA); SEE COMMENT.  Comment:  The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of approximately 3:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. In addition to features of androgenetic alopecia, there is also an isolated follicle with follicular distortion and surrounding fibrosis. The findings are favored to represent trauma-related findings such as can be seen in traction alopecia. The findings are not typical for those of lupus erythematosus in this case. Differentiation between these scarring processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in early lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. At this level of sectioning, very few of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context. 벣D18-62464베. Upper occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% TRACTION ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH TRICHOTILLOMANIA, see comment below. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ttm%%  B. Occipital lower scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% TRACTION ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH TRICHOTILLOMANIA, see comment below.  Comment:  The findings are consistent with traction injury and are, therefore, compatible with trichotillomania. There is a slight increase in vellus hairs suggestive of a background of early androgenetic alopecia. The overlying epidermis shows changes of lichen simplex chronicus. Diagnostic features of psoriasis and seborrheic dermatitis are not seen.   Sections show no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased and there are pigment casts and traumatized hair follicles with follicular distortion. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus) (performed on both biopsies). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ttm%% 3/15/2018

벣D18-63396베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. No features of a contact dermatitis or lichen planopilaris are seen. Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/19/2018
벣D18-63981베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM AND EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show an increase in telogen hairs of up to 30 percent, consistent with telogen effluvium. There is a slight increase in miniaturized hairs and an increase in follicular streamers in the subcutis, suggestive of early androgenetic alopecia. New onset telogen effluvium, or recurrent chronic telogen effluvium, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia. There is focal follicular distortion and perifollicular fibrosis which may be secondary to folliculitis, as one follicle with focal intrafollicular neutrophils is also seen. There is no follicular dropout, sebaceous glands are present, and diagnostic features of a scarring alopecia are not appreciated. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벣D18-71688베. Left posterior scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 3/26/2018

벣D18-73640베. Left inferior posterior neck, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FOLLICULAR MUCINOSIS (ALOPECIA MUCINOSA) (SEE COMMENT).  Comment: Several studies have demonstrated that there are no reliable histologic, immunophenotypic, or even molecular studies to definitively distinguish between idiopathic follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa) and follicular mucinosis associated with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and the findings in this biopsy would be consistent with either, in the appropriate clinical context.  Sections show mucin within the follicular epithelium.  There is a folliculotropic T-cell infiltrate. A CD3 positive T-cell infiltrate is present and involves the follicular epithelium. There appears to be an increased CD4:CD8 ratio. Scattered CD20 positive cells are present. No definitive loss of CD7 is appreciated. Scattered CD30 positive cells are present. Overall, the histologic findings are consistent with follicular mucinosis. The interfollicular epithelium is largely spared. Slight epidermal spongiosis with parakeratosis are also present.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Jose Plaza who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fmyx%%  B. Left superior medial lower back, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ECZEMATOUS DERMATITIS WITH EOSINOPHILS.  Comment: The histologic features appear different from those in part A. In this biopsy, the findings are consistent with an eczematous dermatitis and given the presence of eosinophils, the most likely diagnoses include an allergic contact dermatitis, a spongiotic drug eruption and atopic dermatitis. No follicular mucinosis is identified. Initial and multiple levels were examined. No fungal hyphae are detected with a PAS stain.  Sections show spongiosis and a superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophils.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ECZD2%% 3/29/2018

벣D18-74133베. Left frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, see comment.  Comment: Approximately 7 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch; normal of approx. 21 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 12 follicles in African-Americans for a 3 mm punch based on extrapolation of data-based 4 mm punch results). Therefore, the total number of hairs is reduced. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is focal trichomalacia with distorted hair follicles as well as focal follicular epithelial separation. These changes can be seen with trauma which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania). Correlation with clinical findings is necessary. Initial and multiple levels were examined.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%trac%%  B. The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization at the borderline limit of normal and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. The histologic findings favor early androgenetic alopecia, though correlation with clinical findings is necessary. 벣D18-74448베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 3/30/2018

벣D18-74882베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FAVOR LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 3/28/2018

The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia or resolving telogen effluvium. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. 벣D18-77383베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% PATCHY LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH FOCAL INTERFACE INJURY. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The changes are subtle.  The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury is lichen planopilaris (LPP) and lupus erythematosus (LE).  Given the lack of interface changes in the interfollicular epidermis or deeper inflammation, LPP is somewhat favored over LE.  The process appears very early with only patchy follicular epithelial changes and without follicle dropout or developed scarring. 벣D18-77549베. Right frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment:   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The histologic findings favor a resolving telogen effluvium, given the moderately increased telogen hairs without significantly increased miniaturized hairs.  Alopecia areata is deemed much less likely given the lack of active inflammation or significantly increased miniaturized hairs.  As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Approximately 31 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. No significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles is appreciated (terminal to vellus hair ratio of 9:1). The percent catagen/telogen is increased, at approximately 27-33% percent. 벣D18-79210베. Right frontoparietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: An inflammatory process is present. In this case, the differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, although overall the findings appear to favor a process of lichen planopilaris over those of lupus erythematosus. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsa%%4/3/2018
벣D18-79400베. Left lateral frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FEMALE PATTERN HAIR LOSS (ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA).  Comment:   Superimposed changes suggestive of early central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia are also present.  Approximately 20 hair follicles are present for evaluation. 벣D18-80753베. Right central occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Clinical correlation is suggested. 벣D18-80972베. Left frontal scalp, Punch 3 mm:%%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 4/5/2018

벣D18-82351베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 4/6/2018

Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.
