벣D18-83955베. Posterior scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The findings in this biopsy are non-specific and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (13) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes psoriatic alopecia and traction alopecia.  The findings of chemotherapy-related alopecia are broad and non-specific, however, it is not favored in this case.  Lichen simplex chronicus changes and non-specific granulomatous inflamation, probably secondary to a ruptured follicle, are also present.  As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with parakeratosis with a few neutrophils, associated with a superficial perivascular and deep perifollicular lymphoid infiltrate with plasma cells.  There is a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs and foci of sebaceous gland atrophy.  There is focal sparse peribulbar lymphocytic inflammation with pigment incontinence and the focal suggestion of traumatized hair follicles.  Focal perifollicular granulomatous inflammation is also noted.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%%  4/10/2018
벣D18-84305베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING, INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, some of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and focal interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벣D18-84679베. Left occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% PATCHY LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH FOCAL FOLLICULAR INTERFACE INJURY. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury is lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus.  Differentiation between these two processes can be difficult on biopsies which do not contain sufficient subcutis or a significant number of hair follicles for evaluation (i.e. in a small biopsy often smaller than 4 mm), as is the case in this biopsy, and as the distinction is based on a variety of factors, including examination of the depth of the inflammation, presence of deep dermal mucin deposition, involvement of interfollicular epithelium, and perivascular extension of inflammation.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Syphilitic alopecia can show some overlapping features as seen in this biopsy, but this is less favored, and the T. pallidum immunostain is negative (an RPR is recommended if clinically indicated).  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, some of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and rare interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsai%% The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).4/11/2018

A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벣D18-92219베. Top of scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SEE COMMENT.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would are in favor with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%  B. 벣D18-96461베. Central anterior frontal scalp at hairline, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA WITH INTERFACE INJURY (please see comment).  Comment:  The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury is lichen planopilaris (slightly favored) and lupus erythematosus.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a dense lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. The infiltrate extends somewhat deep and shows areas of perivascular inflammation as well.  There is no appreciable increase in interstitial mucin.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for basement membrane thickening or fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. 벣D18-97256베. Left medial temple, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SUPERFICIAL AND DEEP LYMPHOID INFILTRATE WITH EOSINOPHILS, see comment.  Comment: Given the clinical findings provided, the histologic features are consistent with a drug eruption. Of note, mucin is seen within the follicular epithelium which raises the possibility of follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa); however, this histologic feature can also be seen as an incidental finding in other inflammatory  conditions, and correlation with clinical findings is necessary. If the condition persists despite adequate treatment, additional sampling should be considered.  Sections show a superficial and deep perivascular and interstitial lymphoid infiltrate with prominent eosinophils. There is mucin within the follicular epithelium and intraepithelial lymphocytes in the follicular epithelium.  There is no significant lymphocytic exocytosis in the interfollicular epithelium. Immunohistochemical stains were performed to evaluate the composition of the lymphoid infiltrate. The lymphocytes in the follicular epithelium are composed predominantly of CD3-positive T-lymphocytes with a normal ratio of CD4 and CD8 and normal staining with CD7. CD20 highlights scattered B-lymphocytes.  The immunohistochemical findings are consistent with a reactive infiltrate. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Initial and multiple levels were examined. This case was reviewed at dermatopathology case conference with members of our physician staff. This case was reviewed by Dr. Scott Wickless. The findings were discussed with Dr. Peterson on 4/25/18. %%88305%%%%de%% 4/25/2018
벣D18-97588베. Mid parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (20) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia (slightly favored), resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 4/24/2018
벣D18-97918베. Rt top scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND PROBABLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The findings in this biopsy show both miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with  concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). 벣D18-103952베. Parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA.  Comment: Given the clinical impression, lichen planopilaris is favored despite overlapping histologic features with central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and patchy interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate (6/12 follicles affected). No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. There is also an increase in miniaturized hairs, consistent with a background of early androgenetic alopecia. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 5/1/2018
벣D18-104081베. Right mid parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. Some sections also show a slight increase in telogen hairs (up to 17% of the larger terminal hairs), suggesting, but not diagnostic for, concomitant telogen effluvium. New onset telogen effluvium, or recurrent chronic telogen effluvium, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia. Clinical correlation is advised. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 5/1/2018
벣D18-104262베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 5/1/2018

벣D18-104452베. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 5/1/2018

At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate perifollicular fibrosis, and focal interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. 벣D18-104977베. Vertex scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings are consistent with early androgenetic alopecia, however, there is a slight increase in telogen hairs (15%) which can be seen in early androgenetic alopecia, however, a concomitant telogen effluvium cannot be entirely excluded. No significant inflammation is present. Scarring is absent. New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Initial and multiple levels were examined.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 5/3/2018
벣D18-105076베. Right frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SEE COMMENT.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia or resolving telogen effluvium. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio and percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who is in concurrence with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 5/4/2018
벣D18-105234베. Right posterior scalp, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% PATCHY LICHENOID INTERFACE DERMATITIS, FAVOR DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS (SEE COMMENT).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation, a slight increase in dermal mucin, and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.     As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, if an additional biopsy is clinically indicated, a punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge may be considered. Initial and multiple levels were examined. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%%  5/3/2018

벣D18-107255베. Right occipital scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH COMPONENT OF SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS AND ADMIXED ACUTE FOLLICULITIS.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  Sections also show acanthosis, spongiosis, foci of parakeratosis accentuated at the follicular ostia, and a perivascular lymphoid infiltrate with focal acute folliculitis. 벣D18-107859베. Left ventral distal forearm, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% ULCERATED BASAL CELL CARCINOMA, SUPERFICIAL AND NODULAR TYPES; EXTENDING TO THE DEEP MARGIN.  Comment:   Sections show downward budlike aggregates of polygonal basaloid cells attached to the epidermal undersurface, and lobular aggregates of basaloid cells embedded in a fibromyxoid stroma. %%88305%%%%bccsn%%  B. Left medial superior chest, Shave Biopsy:%%P%% BASAL CELL CARCINOMA, SUPERFICIAL AND NODULAR TYPES; EXTENDING TO ONE PERIPHERAL MARGIN AND TO THE DEEP MARGIN.  Comment:   Sections show downward budlike aggregates of polygonal basaloid cells attached to the epidermal undersurface, and lobular aggregates of basaloid cells embedded in a fibromyxoid stroma. %%88305%%%%bccsn%%  C. Right occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The overall changes are most consistent with a resolving folliculitis decalvans.  Lichen planopilaris is within the differential with few foci of superficial folliculitis.  The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia.  It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris, acne keloidalis, and discoid lupus. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular focal acute and predominantly chronic lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle distortion with perifollicular 'onion-skinning' fibrosis.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%% 5/7/2018
벣D18-107904베. Left central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTIC INFLAMMATORY SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   While the histology somewhat favors central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris would overall be favored given the clinical impression.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 5/4/2018
벣D18-108120베. Left lateral temple, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FOLLICULITIS DECALVANS.  Comment: The folliculitis decalvans pattern of scarring alopecia is seen in scalp biopsies of advanced inflammatory cicatricial alopecia. It is most commonly seen in the advanced stage of central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA), although it can occasionally be seen in the setting of other scarring alopecias, such as lichen planopilaris. The degree of inflammation and follicle destruction makes assessment for an underlying cause difficult.   Sections show dense dermal peri-infundibular acute and chronic inflammation with intrafollicular pustule formation, and follicle destruction with giant cell reaction to hair shaft material. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  These are not the typical findings of dissecting cellulitis. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fd%%5/8/2018

While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy. 벣D18-109484베. Mid frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EARLY CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA. SEE COMMENT. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%%  B. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% RUPTURED SUPPURATIVE FOLLICULITIS. SEE COMMENT %%88305%%%%sfr%%%%88312%%   C. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% EARLY CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment for A, B & C:  While the majority of the biopsy shows changes reminiscent of central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), one follicle has features most consistent with folliculitis decalvans. Folliculitis decalvans, characterized clinically as having frequent perifollicular papules and pustules and almost always most severe on the posterior vertex, is considered by some authors to represent the 'highly inflammatory' end of the CCCA spectrum. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 5/8/2018

At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. Many of the remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. 벣D18-110475베. Left scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. The findings are consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context. Of note, there is a mild increase in telogen hairs, and a new onset telogen effluvium, or recurrent chronic telogen effluvium, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia. Clinical correlation is advised.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. Initial and multiple levels were examined. This case was reviewed by Dr. Jonathan Ralston who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 5/10/2018
벣D18-111127베. Scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 5/8/2018

There are background changes suggestive of androgenetic alopecia.   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%sd%%  B. Right posterior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS. 벣D18-113877베. Posterior mid parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SEE COMMENT.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings are in favor with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. 벣D18-118392베. Left superior parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia. Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, several of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate early concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a very sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Initial and level sections were examined.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lmsa%% 5/18/2018
벣D18-118478베. Superior mid forehead, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LATE STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The differential diagnosis for scarring alopecia includes central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia (CCCA), lichen planopilaris (LPP), and lupus erythematosus (LE).  The advanced nature of the findings precludes definitive categorization of the underlying process. An additional punch biopsy from an early lesion (or the advancing edge of the process), preferably 4 mm in size, could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts. There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation. Giant cell reaction to fragmented hair shafts is noted.  Of the remaining hairs seen, there appears to also be a relative slight increase in miniaturized hairs, such that early concomitant androgenetic alopecia is suggested.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%%5/16/2018

벣D18-120824베. Left central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED CHRONIC TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The presence of miniaturized hair follicles with a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, while the decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion and some follicle units with retained sebaceous glands that lack terminal hairs, suggests superimposed chronic traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania).  Interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Sections show a decrease in terminal follicle density, without evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. Miniaturized hair follicles are appreciated with a slight increase in the percentage of catagen/telogen follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagac%% 5/21/2018

벣D18-121366베. Left temporal peak:%%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with  concomitant telogen effluvium (TE).  Approximately 13 hair follicles are present for evaluation (4/13 are affected). There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to over 15-20% in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).   %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 5/19/2018

벣D18-122688베. Right temporal peak, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs.  Approximately 24 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch).  Scarring is absent.  While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased (approximately 4 miniaturized and 12 normal hairs) and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 5/23/2018

Slightly increased telogen hairs and the suggestion of traumatized hair follicles is noted, possibly representing a component of traction alopecia, which can be secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques, or chronic hair plucking.  The differential diagnosis includes a late stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. Comment: Acne keloidalis (AK) shares some histopathologic findings that are similar to central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA) and it is not uncommon for AK and CCCA to be found in association with each other. 벣D18-124171베. Neck, Punch biopsy: %%P%% MUCINOSIS, FOLLICULAR (ALOPECIA MUCINOSA).  Comment: Several studies have demonstrated that there are no reliable histologic, immunophenotypic, or even molecular studies to definitively distinguish between idiopathic reactive follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa) and follicular mucinosis associated with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and the findings in this biopsy would be consistent with either, in the appropriate clinical context, although the most common type to encounter is reactive and inflammatory rather than neoplastic associated.  Sections show mucin within the follicular epithelium.  There is a sparse folliculotropic lymphoid infiltrate. The interfollicular epithelium is largely spared. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Jose Plaza who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fmyx%%5/24/2018

벣D18-127182베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.  No fungi or basement membrane thickening are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ffalo%%  B. Right neck, Punch: %%P%% ERYTHEMA DYSCHROMICUM PERSTANS (ASHY DERMATOSIS).  Comment: This condition is also known as lichen planus pigmentosus.  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%edp%% 5/28/2018

벣D18-127709베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% END STAGE SCARRING ALOPECIA, FAVOR CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The histologic findings for this scarring alopecia favor central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia.  Approximately 6 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch).  Sections show prominent dermal fibrosis with fibrous tracts and moderate to severe scarring.  There is a marked decrease in follicular unit density and minimal inflammation.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and absent sebaceous glands. Four of the remaining six follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a sparse perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%isa%%  B. Right temporal hairline, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Additionally, focal premature desquamation with eccentric thinning of the follicle and mild perifollicular fibrosis is noted in two follicles, possibly representing a minor component of superimposed early/mild central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia.  Approximately 11 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch).  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased (approximately 4 vellus hairs and 7 terminal hairs present) and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 5/30/2018

벣D18-129092베. Vertical scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment). %%88305%%%%lmsa%%  B. Horizontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (please see comment).  Comment for A&B: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia. The scarring process is advanced and few intact hair follicles present for evaluation. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, argues against the diagnosis of lupus. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and a perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate. Definite interface injury is not identified. The epidermis is mildly acanthotic. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). 벣D18-131067베. Right lower temple, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA (LICHEN PLANOPILARIS).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes frontal fibrosing alopecia/lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of frontal fibrosing alopecia over lupus, particularly in this clinical context.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. 벣D18-133352베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and multiple levels were examined.   Approximately 10 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. 벣D18-133982베. Right superior frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated).  The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs (up to 17% in some sections), without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. 벣D18-135621베. Scalp hairs, Trichogram:%%P%% TERMINAL HAIRS WITH INCREASED TELOGEN COUNT. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   Of the 4 hairs present for evaluation, all are apparent telogen hairs.  No hair shaft abnormality is seen.  Increased telogen hairs can be seen in a variety of alopecias, including telogen effluvium, alopecia areata, traction alopecia, psoriasis, and some inflammatory cicatricial alopecias.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  %%88305%%%%te%% 6/6/2018

벣D18-137082베. Cheek, Shave:%%P%% IRRITATED SEBORRHEIC KERATOSIS. %%88305%%%%sk%%  B. Forehead, Shave:%%P%% FOLLICULAR MUCINOSIS, SEE COMMENT.   Comment: Several studies have demonstrated that there are no reliable histologic, immunophenotypic, or even molecular studies to definitively distinguish between idiopathic follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa) and follicular mucinosis associated with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and the findings in this biopsy would be consistent with either, in the appropriate clinical context. The lymphoid cells are positive for CD3. There are rare CD20+ B-cells in the background. Rare reactive T-cells are positive for CD30. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. 벣D18-140802베. Right parietal scalp, Punch: %%P%% LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. While lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. 벣D18-141177베. Right central frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA (please see comment). 벣D18-141203베. Right lateral submandibular cheek, Punch biopsy: %%P%% FOLLICULAR MUCINOSIS WITH AN ASSOCIATED EOSINOPHIL-RICH INFILTRATE, INCLUDING A COMPONENT OF EOSINOPHILIC PANNICULITIS.  Comment: There is no evidence of granuloma annulare, and there is also no evidence of true Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Rather, The S-100 and CD1a immunostains demonstrate remarkable Langerhans cell hyperplasia in association with a diffuse dermal infiltrate. The primary findings in this biopsy are those of follicular mucinosis, and the eosinophil-rich infiltrate (with associated eosinophilic panniculitis) represents an epiphenomenon.  Follicular mucinosis can serve as a harbinger of underlying cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. In a patient of this age group, the presence of follicular mucinosis may be incidental or may represent so-called acneiform follicular mucinosis, which is often unassociated with underlying lymphoproliferative disease and a reactive process is favored. However, a total skin examination should be completed to screen for the possibility of concomitant mycosis fungoides in this patient. Several studies have demonstrated that there are no reliable histologic, immunophenotypic, or even molecular studies to definitively distinguish between idiopathic follicular mucinosis (alopecia mucinosa) and follicular mucinosis associated with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and the findings in this biopsy would be consistent with either, in the appropriate clinical context, as such appropriate clinical correlation is recommended.  Sections show mucin within the follicular epithelium.  There is a folliculotropic T-cell infiltrate. The interfollicular epithelium is largely spared. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). No fungi or mycobacteria are identified on Gomori's methenamine silver or Fite stains. Immunohistochemical stains were examined (with appropriate controls) and show a heterogeneous T-cell predominant lymphohistiocytoid infiltrate relative to CD30, CD3, CD4, CD8, CD20, immunostaining patterns, supporting the aforementioned diagnosis. Initial and level sections were examined. The submitted clinical note and image are reviewed (and are appreciated). This case was reviewed by Dr. Jose Plaza who concurs with the above interpretation. This case is seen in consultation with the University of California San Francisco Dermatopathology Service (UCSF; Dr. Timothy McCalmont; DL18-62605) with diagnostic agreement, please see attached additional consult report. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fmyx%%   6/19/2018
벣D18-141554베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND POSSIBLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs, without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with possible concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). As it can be difficult to differentiate between early AGA and TE (as early AGA can itself also show a slight increase in telogen hairs), however, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Approximately 33 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased to 18%(6/33) in some sections. There is an increase in miniaturized hair follicles, with a terminal to vellus hair ratio of appoximately 2:1. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). This case was reviewed by Dr. Danielle Wehle who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%% 6/13/2018

벣D18-147455베. Posterior mid parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 6/19/2018
벣D18-147874베. Right parietal scalp, Biopsy: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA CONSISTENT WITH CENTRAL CENTRIFUGAL CICATRICIAL ALOPECIA.  Comment:   At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture, with fibrosis and decreased sebaceous glands. 5 out of the 8 remaining follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibroplasia and eccentric epithelial atrophy. There is a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding the infundibular to isthmic portions of the affected hair follicles. The findings are most consistent with central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. The histologic differential diagnosis includes lichen planopilaris. A PAS stain highlights scattered yeast forms consistent with Pityrosporum; however, no fungal hyphae are identified.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ccca%% 6/18/2018

벣D18-151382베. Mid-occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury and increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyperkeratosis. There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Jose Plaza who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%% 6/21/2018

Comment: The differential diagnosis includes lichen planopilaris and central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia. Thus, clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Initial and multiple levels were examined. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended. The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated).  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 6/26/2018
벣D18-155531베. Mid-occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment:   The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia with interface injury includes lichen planopilaris and lupus erythematosus. The presence of interfollicular interface injury and increased dermal mucin, as well as the depth of perifollicular inflammation and perivascular extension of the inflammation, support the diagnosis of lupus over lichen planopilaris in this biopsy (especially given the definitive changes seen in Part B).  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, many of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate, which extends to the suprabulbar portion of the follicles. The epidermis demonstrates interface injury as well, and acanthosis with hyperkeratosis. There is also an increase in dermal mucin. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lealo%%  B. Left nasal ala, Punch biopsy: %%P%% DISCOID LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS.  Comment:   Sections show epidermal atrophy, hyperkeratosis, vacuolar alteration of the basal layer with apoptosis, thickening of the basement membrane (highlighted on a PAS stain which is negative for fungus), and a superficial and deep perivascular and periadnexal lymphocytic infiltrate with increased dermal mucin. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%dle%% The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated), indicating a history of lupus erythematosus. 6/26/2018

벣D18-156503베. Left medial frontal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% ADVANCED LYMPHOCYTE-MEDIATED SCARRING ALOPECIA (PLEASE SEE COMMENT AND SPECIMEN B).  Comment: The differential diagnosis for lymphocyte-mediated scarring alopecia includes lichen planopilaris, lupus erythematosus, and central centrifugal scarring alopecia.  Given the findings in part B, I favor central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia.  Differentiation between these processes can be difficult on biopsy, particularly in advanced lesions or when there are few intact hair follicles present for evaluation, as is the case in this biopsy. Due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated. No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain. This case was reviewed by Dr. Jyoti Kapil who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%lmsa%%  B. Comment: Acne keloidalis (AK) shares some histopathologic findings that are similar to central centrifugal cicatrial alopecia (CCCA) and it is not uncommon for AK and CCCA to be found in association with each other. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission). 벣D18-161726베. Right superior occipital scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA AND PROBABLE CONCOMITANT TELOGEN EFFLUVIUM. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The findings in this biopsy show both early miniaturization and an increase in telogen hairs (up to 20% of terminal hairs in some sections), without a significant increase in inflammation. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with probable concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). New onset TE, or recurrent chronic TE, may unmask clinically the early stages of AGA, and interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below).  No fungi are detected with a periodic acid-Schiff stain.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagat%%  B. Scarring is absent. Early androgenetic alopecia (AGA) is favored, with probable concomitant telogen effluvium (TE). 벣D18-164296베. Right central parietal scalp, Punch biopsy: %%P%% NON-SCARRING, NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, FAVOR TRAUMATIC ALOPECIA (SEE COMMENT)  Comment: A non-scarring non-inflammatory alopecia is present. There is patchy loss of total hair units and focal perifollicular fibrosis/onion-skinning as can be seen in an early scarring alopecia, however, well-developed scarring alopecia is not identified. Patchy chronic inflammation is present and non-specific; no suppurative folliculitis or dissecting cellulitis is identified. There are slightly increased numbers of telogen follicles with retention of sebaceous glands and a traumatic alopecia is favored, possibly secondary to hair styles, grooming techniques (such as excessive brushing), or chronic hair plucking (trichotillomania). If this histologic findings are not considered representative of the overall clinical process, additional sampling may be considered. Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined. 벣D18-165779베. Right temporal peak, Biopsy: %%P%% PATCHY EARLY SCARRING ALOPECIA. (SEE COMMENT)  Comment:   The changes are not entirely specific, with the differential including one of the scarring alopecias (central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, CCCA, lichen planopilaris, LPP, and lupus erythematosus, LE).  However, rare foci of follicular interface injury is present which favors LPP and LE over CCCA.  Additionally, while lupus cannot be entirely excluded, the lack of interfollicular interface injury or an increase in dermal mucin, as well as the lack of deep perifollicular inflammation or a significant perivascular component to the inflammation, favors the diagnosis of lichen planopilaris over lupus in this biopsy.  At the level of the isthmus, there is disruption of the normal follicular unit architecture,with fibrosis and decreased to absent sebaceous glands. At this level of sectioning, some of the remaining hair follicles demonstrate concentric perifollicular fibrosis, and interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. No interfollicular interface injury is seen at the dermoepidermal junction, and there is no apparent increase in dermal mucin. Approximately 9 hair follicles are present for evaluation (normal of approx. 38 follicles in Caucasians and approx. 21 follicles in African-Americans for a 4 mm punch). Approximately 50% of the remaining hair follicles are affected by the patchy early scarring perifollicular fibrosis and interface injury.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 7/9/2018

There are also background changes of androgenetic alopecia.  The submitted clinical note is reviewed (and is appreciated). 벣P18-76660베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED CHANGES OF TRACTION ALOPECIA.  Comment: The presence of miniaturized hair follicles with a slight increase in catagen/telogen hairs supports the diagnosis of androgenetic alopecia, while the decrease in terminal follicle density with follicular distortion and some follicle units with retained sebaceous glands that lack terminal hairs, suggests superimposed chronic traction alopecia. Interestingly, a study of a large series of alopecia cases showed multifactorial alopecia with 2 or more patterns of alopecia in 12.5% of cases (see reference below). Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Sections show a decrease in terminal follicle density, without evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. There is evidence of follicular distortion and trauma. Miniaturized hair follicles are appreciated with a slight increase in the percentage of catagen/telogen follicles. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). Reference: Wohltmann WE, Sperling L. Histopathologic diagnosis of multifactorial alopecia. J Cutan Pathol. 2016 Jun;43(6):483-91). This case was reviewed by Dr. Daniel Wimmer who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%fagac%% 1/23/2018

벣P18-85812베. Frontal scalp, Shave:%%P%% SUGGESTIVE OF LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: At the level of the isthmus, there is interface injury with a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate. 벬X18-21베. Right mid scalp, Punch bx (D17-4133, CBCC, 12/29/17):%%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: Initial and multiple levels were examined. The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage. 벯Y17-12531베. Left superior frontal scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING ALOPECIA, FAVOR ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA WITH SUPERIMPOSED SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS, see comment.  Comment:  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process. There is an increase in miniaturized follicles as well as sebaceous gland atrophy. Within the subcutis, there are follicular streamers. The overlying epidermis shows acanthosis, mild spongiosis, and parakeratosis with a superficial perivascular lymphoid infiltrate and a few eosinophils. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case is difficult as these histologic features can be seen in androgenetic alopecia with seborrheic dermatitis as well as in psoriatic alopecia.  Although psoriasis cannot be entirely excluded, given the clinical findings provided and the overall histologic features, androgenetic alopecia with superimposed seborrheic dermatitis is favored.  This case was discussed with Amy Matorin, PA. This case was reviewed at dermatopathology case conference with members of our physician staff. This case was also reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%aga%%1/5/2018

벯Y18-537베. Crown of scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, SUGGESTIVE OF EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA, see comment.  Comment: Sections show a slight increase in miniaturized hair follicles. There is no significant increase in inflammation, and scarring is absent. The histologic features are suggestive of early androgenetic alopecia.  A slight increase in telogen hairs is also noted. New onset telogen effluvium, or recurrent chronic telogen effluvium, may unmask clinically the early stages of androgenetic alopecia. Clinical correlation is necessary. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation. %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%% 1/11/2018
벯Y18-2937베. Right parietal scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA, CONSISTENT WITH  EARLY ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle, with the suggestion of early miniaturization and without evidence of a significant increase in inflammation or telogen hairs. Scarring is absent. While the findings would be consistent with early androgenetic alopecia in the appropriate clinical context, clinicopathologic correlation is required in this case, due to the subtly of the histologic findings. The differential diagnosis of subtle histologic findings in the clinical setting of a perceived alopecia would also include an area biopsied that is in the recovery phase of a pre-existing alopecia (such as resolving telogen effluvium or alopecia areata that has gone into remission) or a hair shaft disorder with external hair breakage.  If clinically indicated, paired punch biopsies (preferably 4 mm in size) from the most involved zone of alopecia and normal uninvolved scalp may be helpful in establishing a more definitive diagnosis.  Initial and multiple deeper sections were examined.  Sections show a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The number of miniaturized hairs is slightly increased and the percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles is essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). This case was reviewed by Dr. Prasanna Sinkre and by Dr. Sadia Salim who concur with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%faga%%  B. Right posterior scalp, Shave:%%P%% PSORIASIFORM AND SPONGIOTIC DERMATITIS CONSISTENT WITH PSORIASIS.  Comment: The presence of parakeratosis with diminished granular layer, prominence of the dermal papillae vasculature, and lack of conspicuous eosinophils, all favor the diagnosis of psoriasis over eczematous dermatitis in this biopsy. No fungal hyphae are detected with a PAS stain.  Sections show psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with spongiosis, foci of neutrophilic parakeratosis, and partial diminution of the granular layer. There is dilation of the dermal papillae vasculature, and an associated perivascular predominantly lymphoid infiltrate. This case was reviewed by Dr. Prasanna Sinkre and by Dr. Sadia Salim who concur with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%psdps%% 2/1/2018
벯Y18-4178베. Scalp, Punch: %%P%% SCARRING ALOPECIA, MOST CONSISTENT WITH LICHEN PLANOPILARIS.  Comment: Although central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia was considered, it is not favored. Initial and multiple levels were examined. Sections show peri-infundibular inflammation and fibrosis.    A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%lpp%% 2/9/2018
벯Y18-6624베. Left superior occipital scalp, Punch: %%P%% NON-SCARRING NON-INFLAMMATORY ALOPECIA.  Comment: The findings in this biopsy are subtle and interpretation is also limited due to the relatively small number of follicular units present (11) for evaluation, precluding a more definitive diagnosis. The differential diagnosis includes an early stage of androgenetic alopecia, resolving telogen effluvium, or alopecia areata that has gone into remission. As most histologic data on transverse sections for alopecia are based upon 4 mm punch biopsy specimens, and due to the sampling variability inherent in scalp biopsies for alopecia, a repeat punch biopsy, preferably of 4 mm in size, from the advancing edge could be considered for further evaluation, if clinically indicated.  There is a slight decrease in follicle density, with no evidence of scarring or significant inflammation. The terminal to vellus hair ratio and percentage of catagen/telogen hair follicles are essentially within normal limits.  A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus).  This case was reviewed by Dr. Darren Whittemore who concurs with the above interpretation.  %%88305%%%%88312%%%%nsnia%% 3/8/2018

An inflammatory cell infiltrate is present at the base of the lesion. %%88305%%%%pskif%%  B. L posterior parietal scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH ANDROGENETIC ALOPECIA.  Comment:  There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is within normal limits. There is a significant increase in miniaturized hair follicles. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. 벯Y18-13174베. Left vertex of scalp, Punch: %%P%% CONSISTENT WITH TRICHOTILLOMANIA.  Comment: The findings are consistent with traction injury and are, therefore, compatible with the clinical impression of trichotillomania.  A less-likely differential diagnosis could include alopecia areata.  Approximately 6 hair follicles are present for evaluation. There is no evidence of scarring or a significant inflammatory process, and the epidermis is unremarkable. The percentage of catagen/telogen hairs is increased and there are pigment casts and traumatized hair follicles. There is preservation of vellus hairs. Within the subcutis, there is an increase in follicular streamers. A periodic acid-Schiff stain was utilized in the diagnostic evaluation (and is negative for fungus). %%88305%%%%88312%%%%ttm%% 5/9/2018
